title: 105_hr1429
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 1997" and references amendments to the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965. The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 1997" eliminates the growth center requirement and updates the statement of purpose to address new challenges facing rural areas, particularly in the Appalachian region. The Act aims to help Appalachia develop a skilled workforce, improve infrastructure, foster economic growth, and achieve self-sustainability. The Commission is tasked with advocating for and partnering with the region to achieve these goals. The Commission, under this Act, advocates for Appalachia's people and aims for a self-sustaining economy based on principles like investing in people, promoting entrepreneurial economies, engaging in the global economy, community-based development, utilizing technology, and fostering open communication among stakeholders. The Commission shall focus special attention on areas of greatest need in the region to promote productive communication among stakeholders. The Commission shall hold meetings to promote communication among stakeholders in areas of greatest need. The Commission is required to conduct at least one annual meeting with the Federal Co-Chairman and a majority of State members present. Additional meetings can be held electronically as deemed necessary. Decisions requiring a quorum will be made by the Commission. The amendment to section 101(b) requires a quorum of State members for decisions on Commission policy, approval of development plans, fund allocation, and county designation under section 226. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATIONS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.

Section 105(b) (40 U.S.C. App. 105(b)) is amended to authorize appropriations of $3,645,000 for fiscal year 1998 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1999 through 2002 for expenses related to the Federal Co-Chairman.

SEC. 5. COMPENSATION OF EMPLOYEES. SEC. 5. COMPENSATION OF EMPLOYEES. Section 106(2) is amended to set the maximum rate for the Senior Executive Service under title 5, United States Code. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF LEASE TERMS. Section 106(7) is amended to change the year from 1982 to 2002. SEC. 7. HIGHWAY SYSTEM. SEC. 7. HIGHWAY SYSTEM. Authorization of $90,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and additional funding for fiscal years 1999 through 2002. Cost sharing rule amended to increase federal contribution to 80 percent. SEC. 8 amends section 214(a) to allow the Federal Co-Chairman to use available funds. It also defines Federal Grant-in-Aid Programs and limits covered road projects to those authorized by title 23, United States Code. SEC. 9 establishes program development criteria. SEC. 9 amends program development criteria to include distressed and underdeveloped areas, adds outcome measurement requirements, and prohibits financial assistance for relocating establishments. SEC. 10 amends Part C of title II to include provisions for distressed and economically strong counties. The Commission designates distressed counties and economically strong counties, including competitive and attainment counties, based on specific criteria. The Commission gives special consideration to distressed counties in program development and funding allocation under the Act. Assistance is limited for projects in competitive counties and prohibited for projects in economically strong counties. The prohibitions on project funding do not apply to certain exceptions, such as projects on the Appalachian development highway system, local development district administrative projects, or multicounty projects where all counties share costs and benefits. The Commission may waive these prohibitions for specific projects under certain conditions. The Commission may waive prohibitions on project funding under certain conditions, based on criteria such as significant distress in the county, economic decline not reflected in data, or potential benefits outside the designated county. SEC. 11. Grants for administrative expenses and demonstration projects; availability of amounts. Section 302(a) (40 U.S.C. App. 302(a)) is amended by changing references from "The President" to "The Commission" and removing instances of "to the Commission" in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3). SEC. 12. Authorization of appropriations for general program. Section 401 (40 U.S.C. App. 401) authorizes $71,355,000 for fiscal year 1998 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1999 through 2002 for the Commission to carry out the Act. SEC. 13 extends the termination date to 2002. SEC. 14 states that the Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 1997.
